questionList.questionText: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her parents due to depressive symptoms for the past month.  Prior to evaluation, the parents share that they received a phone call from her roommate, who told them that the patient was having thoughts about killing herself.  The roommate also told them that the patient had not been attending classes for the past week and was sleeping and watching television in her dorm room instead.  At the start of the evaluation, the patient appears upset and yells at her parents for bringing her to the hospital.  She then says to the physician, "I don't need to be here.  I feel fine.  My roommate got scared and called my parents."  Which of the following is the most appropriate statement?
questionList.explanationText:
Management of suicidality

Management

Imminent risk of suicide (voiced intent, high number of unmanaged risk factors, collateral concerns raised)

  • Ensure safety: hospitalize immediately (involuntary if necessary) & start 1:1 for constant observation
  • Remove personal belongings & objects in room that may present self-harm risk
  • Security may be required to hold against will
 

Nonimminent risk of suicide (no intent, strong social supports available, outpatient follow-up plan is reasonable)

  • Create safety plan (eg, coping skills, social supports, crisis numbers)
  • Ensure close follow-up (eg, psychiatry, therapy, intensive outpatient program)
  • Plan to address modifiable risk factors (eg, depression, psychosis, substance use, pain)
  • Ensure family or friends available to support patient
  • Remove access to potential means (eg, secure firearms & medications)

This patient has a depressive disorder as evidenced by suicidality, hypersomnia, and loss of motivation (eg, not attending classes).  She expressed suicidal ideation, indicating an imminent risk for self-harm that prompted her parents to bring her to the emergency department for a suicide risk assessment.  When these assessments are unexpected or not patient-initiated, patient reactions can range from relief to anger.  Some may deny or resist further discussion.  Nevertheless, physicians must complete a thorough assessment for patient safety.

An empathic and validating approach is usually more productive with a reluctant patient.  Part of this patient's resistance likely stems from anger and surprise that a conversation with her roommate escalated to a phone call to her parents and the emergency department visit.  Most likely she feels threatened and exposed; therefore, a nonthreatening approach is needed to gradually build trust and rapport.

Because the assessment was prompted by her roommate, it may be helpful to focus on what prompted the friend's concern (and remind the patient that she has her support).  Asking the patient to reflect on her roommate's thought process (eg, "what do you think caused your roommate to feel scared?") is less intimidating and may gradually encourage the patient to talk and disclose details (eg, ideation, intent, plan) needed to guide management.  In contrast, beginning with questions on suicidality (eg, "how long have you been thinking about ending your life?") is abrupt, invasive, and may provoke more denial (Choice E).

(Choices A and B)  Physicians should not imply that patients may leave if they cooperate because further conversation could uncover an indication for immediate hospitalization (eg, active suicidal ideation).  Offering medication before speaking with the patient is also likely to offend or undermine rapport.

(Choice D)  This approach is nonthreatening because it does not immediately focus attention on the patient.  However, it is not an open-ended question and requires the patient to listen to the physician rather than encouraging her to reflect and talk.  In addition, emphasizing the parents' perspective may imply that the physician is aligned with the parents, which jeopardizes patient trust.

Educational objective:
With patients who are resistant or reluctant to cooperate with a suicide risk assessment, an empathetic, validating, and nonthreatening approach with an open-ended question is more likely to encourage disclosure of details (eg, ideation, intent, plan).
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Physician patient communication

answerChoiceList.choice: "I understand that you're upset and don't want to be here, but in order for you to leave, we need to talk about how you've been feeling recently."
"I will need to do a full evaluation since there are concerns about your safety; if you're unable to remain calm, I can offer you a medication that may help."
"You weren't expecting a conversation with your roommate would turn into a trip to the hospital; what do you think caused your roommate to feel scared?"
"Your parents think you need an evaluation, but I see that you do not agree; can I share what your parents' concerns are with you?"
"Your roommate wanted to make sure you were safe and got help; how long have you been thinking about ending your life?"

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Suicide.
A risk algorithm for the persistence of suicidal thoughts and behaviors during college.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old man comes to the office due to fatigue and sleep difficulties for the past month.  He describes feeling exhausted when he awakens and has to force himself to get out of bed and get dressed for work.  The patient reports having difficulty falling asleep at night and usually watches television in bed for a few hours.  On the weekends, he takes 2- to 3-hour naps during the day.  The patient also has difficulties concentrating and has become increasingly anxious about his work performance and losing his job due to feeling tired.  He says, "I've missed several deadlines and keep making the same accounting mistakes.  I've been fired before and now I'm afraid it'll happen again.  How will I support my family if that happens?"  The patient has stopped cycling with friends and has not kept up with other hobbies.  Medical history is noncontributory.  Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable apart from a 4.5-kg (9.9-lb) weight gain.  BMI is 25 kg/m2.  Laboratory studies, including thyroid function tests, are within normal limits.  The patient appears restless and tired.  He has no suicidal ideation.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Major depressive disorder vs seasonal affective disorder*

MDD

SAD

Clinical features

  • Single or recurrent major depressive episodes (≥2 weeks of ≥5 of depression + SIG‑E‑CAPS)
  • No seasonal pattern
  • Recurrent major depressive episodes
  • ≥2-year pattern of seasonal recurrence & remission (eg, winter onset–spring remission)
  • No nonseasonal depressive episodes
  • Lifetime seasonal >>> nonseasonal depressive episodes

Management

  • Antidepressant (eg, SSRI)
  • Psychotherapy (CBT)
  • Combined therapy
  • Antidepressant (eg, SSRI) + light therapy
  • Psychotherapy (CBT)
  • Behavioral (eg, outdoor walks, aerobic exercise, sleep hygiene)

*Seasonal affective disorder = major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern.

CBT = cognitive-behavioral therapy; MDD = major depressive disorder; SAD = seasonal affective disorder; SIG‑E‑CAPS = Sleep, Interest, Guilt, Energy, Concentration, Appetite, Psychomotor changes, Suicidality; SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

This patient's presentation is consistent with major depressive disorder (MDD), given his anhedonia (eg, stopped spending time with friends, discontinued hobbies [eg, cycling]); sleep difficulties; low energy and fatigue; impaired concentration (eg, missed deadlines, mistakes at work); weight gain; and psychomotor agitation (eg, increasingly anxious, restless) that have lasted ≥2 weeks.

Initial treatment of MDD may include antidepressants, psychotherapy, or a combination of both.

  • Antidepressant efficacy is generally comparable across and within classes and is comparable to psychotherapy alone.  Most patients are treated with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (eg, escitalopram) for a first episode, but other classes (eg, serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors) can be selected based on additional factors (eg, adverse effects, comorbidities).

  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy for depression (which focuses on identifying maladaptive beliefs and using behavioral techniques such as exercise to alleviate their effects) and interpersonal psychotherapy (which focuses on interpersonal conflicts, grief, role changes) are efficacious and have benefits that extend beyond the acute treatment period.

Combined therapy consisting of antidepressant plus psychotherapy is more effective than either alone.

(Choice A)  Buspirone can be used to augment a first-line antidepressant (eg, citalopram, escitalopram) in cases of a partial response; however, it is not used as a first-line option by itself.  In addition, psychodynamic psychotherapy (aimed at developing insight by uncovering unconscious behavior patterns rooted in the past), although helpful for depression, has less evidence of effectiveness compared to cognitive-behavioral therapy.

(Choice B)  Citalopram is a first-line antidepressant used to treat MDD and can be augmented with bright light therapy in seasonal affective disorder (MDD with seasonal pattern).  However, there must be a ≥2-year history of recurrent seasonal onset and remission of depressive episodes to establish the seasonal pattern.  This patient reports symptoms for only the past month and should be treated with an antidepressant plus psychotherapy.

(Choices D and E)  Sleep hygiene is a part of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia, which can be used with or without ramelteon, a melatonin receptor agonist, to manage problematic sleep patterns.  However, these interventions augment, not replace, standard management of MDD.  There should be no delay in establishing effective care for MDD once it is identified.

Educational objective:
Combined antidepressant and psychotherapy management of major depressive disorder is more efficacious than either alone.  Among psychotherapies, cognitive-behavioral therapy and interpersonal psychotherapy have the most evidence demonstrating efficacy.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Depression

answerChoiceList.choice: Escitalopram and cognitive-behavioral therapy focusing on depression
Ramelteon and cognitive-behavioral therapy focusing on insomnia
Sleep hygiene education only with follow-up visit in a month

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Adding psychotherapy to antidepressant medication in depression and anxiety disorders: a meta-analysis.
Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia in patients with mental disorders and comorbid insomnia: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

questionList.questionText: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for assessment of "bad stomach aches."  The patient has missed 5 days of school in the past few weeks due to intermittent abdominal pain that is "achy all over" and worse in the morning.  She has not had associated nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation.  Her appetite is poor.  The mother reports that her daughter used to be talkative and outgoing, but now she declines invitations to play at friends' houses and instead takes naps after school.  The patient has been distracted in class lately and less engaged in group activities.  Her father lost his job 3 months ago and has been home more often since then.  The mother says, "Things have been difficult financially.  It doesn't help that her father has started drinking again."  When interviewed, the patient is withdrawn and makes poor eye contact.  When asked if she feels depressed, she says, "Everything will be better when no one has to take care of me anymore."  She avoids answering further questions.  The patient has no significant medical history.  Vital signs and physical examination, including abdominal examination, are normal.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's social withdrawal, poor appetite, impaired concentration, and sleeping during the day are concerning for depression.  As seen in this patient, childhood depression is often associated with somatic symptoms such as stomach aches and headaches because children often have difficulty recognizing or discussing their emotions.  Any child with a change in behavior in the context of family stress and parental substance use should be assessed for child abuse.  This girl's avoidance of answering most questions is worrisome.  In addition, her refusal to directly answer whether she is depressed, saying that "everything will be better when no one has to take care of me anymore," is particularly concerning for possible suicidal ideation.

The most appropriate next step is to obtain an emergency psychiatric assessment that can assist in determining if psychiatric hospitalization is necessary.  Considerations for inpatient care include suicidal ideation, poor psychosocial support, and lack of psychiatric follow-up (as an outpatient).  This patient has poor psychosocial support with ongoing familial stressors and no current psychiatric care.  She should not be sent home until further evaluation of her safety takes place.

(Choices A and B)  Contacting the patient's school and arranging for an in-home social work assessment can be helpful in understanding the case factors involved and making appropriate recommendations for treatment and support that involve both the school and family.  However, information from the school may be insufficient to rule out suicidality or abuse, and the child should not be sent home until her safety is established.

(Choices C and D)  Checking a comprehensive metabolic panel and obtaining an ultrasound are appropriate if there is concern for medical causes of abdominal pain (eg, localized pain or guarding, rebound on examination).  However, these are unlikely to be helpful in a patient with nonspecific aches and a normal physical examination.  In addition, the results of these tests take time, and suicidality and safety are immediate concerns.

(Choices F and G)  Antidepressants and/or psychotherapy (individual, family) are appropriate treatments for pediatric depression.  However, an assessment of suicide risk and a determination of the appropriate level of care should take place first.

Educational objective:
In children and adolescents with depression, considerations for inpatient treatment include suicidal ideation, poor psychosocial support, and lack of psychiatric follow-up.  Any child who has possible thoughts of suicide must undergo emergency assessment for safety.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Suicide

answerChoiceList.choice: Arrange for an in-home social work assessment
Contact the patient's school for further information
Obtain an emergency assessment for possible hospitalization

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Suicide in childhood: a literatura review.

questionList.questionText: A 16-year-old girl comes to the office for psychiatric follow-up accompanied by her mother.  The patient has a history of depression and was started on fluoxetine 2 weeks ago.  Her energy and appetite have improved, but she still struggles with feelings of sadness and low self-esteem.  She has difficulty fitting in with social groups at school and tends to keep to herself.  The patient's depression was diagnosed at age 14 after she attempted suicide by an overdose of 15 acetaminophen tablets.  At that time, she was being sexually abused by a friend of the family; the abuse has since stopped.  She also has a history of cutting behavior and self-induced vomiting.  The patient uses marijuana and alcohol and has tried cocaine twice but did not like it.  Family history is significant for depression in her mother and suicide in her father.  The patient has had fleeting thoughts that she would be "better off dead" and "wonders how people would feel if I were gone," but she has had no suicidal intent or suicide plan.  Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for suicide in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Suicide risk & protective factors

Risk factors

  • Psychiatric disorders, prior suicide attempts
  • Hopelessness  
  • Never married, divorced, separated
  • Living alone
  • Unemployed or unskilled
  • Physical illness
  • Family history of suicide, family discord
  • Access to firearms
  • Substance abuse, impulsivity

Protective factors

  • Social support/family connectedness
  • Pregnancy
  • Parenthood
  • Religion & participation in religious activities

This patient has a number of predisposing factors that increase her risk for suicide, including a psychiatric disorder, previous suicide attempt, history of cutting (nonsuicidal self-injury) and sexual abuse, and family history of suicide.  Additional factors include her social isolation and use of drugs and alcohol.  The strongest single factor predictive of suicide, however, is her history of a prior suicide attempt (ie, acetaminophen overdose), as previous behavior predicts future behavior.

Comprehensive suicide assessment includes evaluation of both risk and protective factors.  Elderly persons (age >65), especially elderly white men, are at increased risk of suicide.  The suicide rate for adolescents and young adults (age 15-24) also remains high, with impulsivity, hopelessness, substance use, and suicide contagion contributing largely to the rate.

(Choices A, B, C, E, and G)  Family history of suicide and personal history of cutting behavior, depression, sexual abuse, and social isolation are all lesser risk factors.

(Choice F)  Although a slightly increased risk of suicidality has been reported in adolescents treated with antidepressant medications compared with placebo, this patient's history of suicide attempt is a much stronger risk factor.

(Choice H)  The disinhibiting effects of alcohol and drugs frequently contribute to impulsively acting out on suicidal thoughts, especially among adolescents and young adults.  Substance use is a significant risk factor for this patient, but not as strong a factor as her prior suicide attempt.

Educational objective:
The greatest risk factor for suicide is a history of suicide attempt(s).
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Suicide

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Suicide attempt as a risk factor for completed suicide:  even more lethal than we knew.
Suicide and suicide attempts in adolescents.

questionList.questionText: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office due to a 3-week history of depressed mood, low energy, loss of motivation, and oversleeping following the break-up of a relationship.  The patient is sleeping 12 hours each day and describes difficulty getting out of bed and showering and dressing in the morning.  Her concentration is poor at work, and she has difficulty completing everyday tasks.  The patient has no psychotic symptoms or suicidal ideation.  She has a history of major depressive episodes at age 16 and 20.  The patient was treated briefly with fluoxetine at age 20 but stopped the medication after a week as she did not like the way it made her feel.  Following a rape at age 22, she was treated with trauma-focused psychotherapy for 6 months.  The patient has no significant medical history.  She drinks a beer several times a week and uses cannabis approximately once every other month.  Physical examination is normal.  After the physician discusses treatment options for depression, the patient chooses to have combination treatment with psychotherapy and medication.  Which of the following would be most important to obtain prior to initiating pharmacologic treatment for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
All antidepressants can induce mania, with the greatest risk occurring in patients with bipolar disorder.  Therefore, prior to initiating antidepressants for a major depressive episode, all patients should be screened for a history of hypomania/mania to rule out bipolar disorder.  As many patients tend to minimize or have difficulty recalling periods of mood elevation, physicians should inquire about discrete periods of uncharacteristically good or irritable moods, excessive energy, decreased need for sleep, racing thoughts, and risk-taking behavior.  This patient's history of early-onset depression, poor tolerability to a previous trial of antidepressant treatment, and a depressive episode characterized by lethargy and hypersomnia are especially characteristic of bipolar depression and should warrant careful assessment.

Patients who have a major depressive episode and meet criteria for a past manic or hypomanic episode should be diagnosed with bipolar disorder rather than unipolar major depressive disorder.  Antidepressant monotherapy should be avoided in these patients due to the risk of inducing hypomania/mania.

(Choices A, E, and F)  Routine screening laboratory tests (eg, complete blood count, metabolic panel, thyroid function tests, urine toxicology screen) are not a priority for this patient with a history of depression and acute onset following a psychosocial stressor, no significant medical history, normal physical examination, and minimal substance use.  Selected laboratory tests should be performed in cases of new-onset or treatment-resistant depression or in patients who experience new-onset physical symptoms along with depression.

(Choices B and C)  Although assessing for comorbid illness such as post-traumatic stress disorder and anxiety disorders would be helpful to gain a deeper understanding of the patient, the most important step in this case is to rule out bipolar disorder.  An in-depth trauma history is best obtained by a trained therapist after rapport is established.

Educational objective:
All patients who have a major depressive episode should be screened for a history of hypomanic/manic episodes to rule out bipolar disorder.  This is especially important prior to being prescribed antidepressants due to the risk of antidepressant-induced mania.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Antidepressants

answerChoiceList.choice: Complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel

questionMappingReferencesList.title: The risk of switch to mania in patients with bipolar disorder during treatment with an antidepressant alone and in combination with a mood stabilizer.

questionList.questionText:
A 38-year-old man comes to the office due to disturbed sleep and depressed mood for the past several months.  The patient has difficulty falling and staying asleep and says, "I lie awake at night thinking about all the weight I've gained and how I am too tired to even do anything about it."  He constantly feels exhausted at work, which involves "sitting all day in a cubicle."  The patient has also felt depressed and irritable, which he attributes to his appearance.  He has no previous medical conditions and takes no medications.  Family history is significant for bipolar disorder in his brother.  Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), blood pressure is 148/90 mm Hg, and pulse is 86/min.  BMI is 34 kg/m2.  On physical examination, the patient has a flat affect and a ruddy appearance with central obesity.  The thyroid is normal to palpation.  The lungs are clear to auscultation and heart sounds are normal.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  There is no extremity edema.  Proximal limb muscles are mildly weak with no associated pain or tenderness.  The patient is tearful throughout the evaluation but has no suicidal ideation.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin14.4 g/dL
    Platelets320,000/mm3
    Leukocytes9,000/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Sodium140 mEq/L
    Potassium3.4 mEq/L
    Creatinine1.0 mg/dL
    Glucose140 mg/dL
TSH2.9 µU/mL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Features of Cushing syndrome

Clinical manifestations

  • Central obesity
  • Skin atrophy & wide, purplish striae
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Hypertension
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Skin hyperpigmentation (if due to ACTH excess)
  • Depression, anxiety

Diagnosis

  • 24-hr urinary cortisol excretion
  • Late-night salivary cortisol assay
  • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test

This patient's depression and sleep disturbances, in the context of centralized obesity, proximal muscle weakness, a ruddy appearance, hypertension, hypokalemia, and hyperglycemia, are suggestive of Cushing syndrome.  Cushing syndrome is characterized by excess cortisol production, most commonly due to adrenal disorders, ACTH-producing pituitary adenomas, or ectopic ACTH production.  Other manifestations of hypercortisolism include hirsutism, bone loss, easy bruising, and hypokalemia (due to cortisol's mineralocorticoid effects).

Neuropsychiatric symptoms in Cushing syndrome are common and include depressed or labile mood, anxiety or panic attacks, irritability, insomnia, memory deficits, and fatigue.  Mania and paranoia occasionally occur.  Patients who initially have psychiatric symptoms may be mistakenly diagnosed with a primary psychiatric disorder.

Patients with new-onset depression associated with physical or laboratory abnormalities warrant medical evaluation for underlying metabolic causes of depressed mood.  Initial diagnostic tests for Cushing syndrome include 24-hour urinary cortisol excretion, late-night salivary cortisol assay, and overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test.

(Choice A)  Anti–Jo-1 antibodies are specific for polymyositis and dermatomyositis.  These inflammatory myopathies are characterized by proximal muscle weakness, with (dermatomyositis) or without (polymyositis) characteristic skin manifestations.  However, affective symptoms, as well as central obesity, ruddy appearance, hyperglycemia, and hypokalemia, are more consistent with Cushing syndrome.

(Choice C)  Insulin-like growth factor-1 is elevated in acromegaly, which can cause hyperglycemia and weight gain.  It is accompanied by overgrowth of soft tissue, which manifests with enlarged jaws and facial features, hands, and feet.  However, it is not typically associated with centralized obesity, a ruddy appearance, or hypokalemia.

(Choices D and E)  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (eg, paroxetine) and cognitive-behavioral therapy are first-line treatments for major depressive disorder.  Before a primary depressive disorder is diagnosed, however, medical causes of depressed mood, such as Cushing syndrome, must be ruled out.

(Choice F)  Bariatric surgery is generally indicated for patients with a BMI ≥40 kg/m2 or for those with a BMI ≥35 kg/m2 in association with obesity-related comorbidities (eg, type 2 diabetes mellitus).  This patient's weight gain is likely a manifestation of hypercortisolism, which should be treated prior to consideration of bariatric surgery.

Educational objective:
Neuropsychiatric manifestations of Cushing syndrome include depressed or labile mood, anxiety, irritability, insomnia, memory deficits, and fatigue.  Patients with these symptoms may be mistakenly diagnosed with primary psychiatric disorders.  Initial diagnostic tests include 24-hour urinary cortisol excretion, late-night salivary cortisol assay, and overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test.

questionList.title: Depression

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Psychiatric symptoms in patients with Cushing's syndrome: prevalence, diagnosis and management.
Psychiatric disorders associated with Cushing's syndrome.

questionList.questionText: A 74-year-old man is hospitalized due to severe depression and a 9-kg (19.8-lb) weight loss over the last month.  The patient has become progressively withdrawn from friends and family, stopped attending his weekly bridge game, and refuses to leave the house to visit his children and grandchildren.  He sleeps poorly and ruminates at night about his financial situation and past events such as fighting with his brother when they were adolescents.  The patient has a history of depression and responded to treatment with a tricyclic antidepressant 30 years ago.  A recent trial of a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor was ineffective and was discontinued.  The patient has a history of controlled hypertension and a myocardial infarction 10 years ago from which he recovered completely.  In the hospital, efforts to get him to eat and drink are unsuccessful.  On mental status examination, the patient's eyes are downcast and he gives brief, barely audible responses.  He reluctantly discloses that he has been hearing the voice of his brother, who died 15 years ago, accusing him of committing multiple crimes.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Electroconvulsive therapy for depression

 

Indications

  • Treatment resistance
  • Psychotic features
  • Emergency conditions
    • Pregnancy
    • Refusal to eat or drink
    • Imminent risk for suicide
 

Safety

  • No absolute contraindications
  • Increased risk  
    • Severe cardiovascular disease,
      recent myocardial infarction
    • Space-occupying brain lesion
    • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

This patient's severe depression, loss of interest, excessive guilt, sleep and appetite disturbance, and auditory hallucinations are consistent with major depression with psychotic features.  His marked weight loss and refusal to eat and drink require urgent treatment.  According to multiple evidence-based guidelines, first-line treatment of psychotic depression consists of either an antidepressant plus an antipsychotic or electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).  Because ECT is generally faster than pharmacotherapy, it is used to achieve a rapid response in depressed elderly patients who are unable to eat and drink, psychotic, or actively suicidal.  ECT involves inducing a 30- to 60-second generalized tonic-clonic seizure.  Hemodynamic changes are brief and cardiac complications are rare.  Amnesia (typically short-lived) is one of the most common side effects.

Antidepressants typically take up to 6-8 weeks for response and must be combined with an antipsychotic medication to effectively treat major depression with psychotic features (Choices D, E, and F).  Although the patient's condition previously responded to a tricyclic antidepressant, antidepressant monotherapy would now be inadequate, and ECT is preferred due to the need for rapid response in this severely depressed patient who is not eating or drinking.

(Choice A)  Antipsychotic monotherapy would not adequately treat this patient's depression.  The combination of an antidepressant and an antipsychotic would be appropriate in a less urgent situation.

(Choice B)  Cognitive-behavioral therapy alone would not be sufficient due to the severity of depression, presence of psychotic features, and need for rapid response.

Educational objective:
Electroconvulsive therapy is an evidence-based treatment for major depression that carries a low risk for complications.  It is a first-line treatment for major depression with psychotic features and appropriate for severely depressed elderly patients who are not eating or drinking and require rapid intervention.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Depression

questionMappingReferencesList.title: The role of electroconvulsive and neuromodulation therapies in the treatment of geriatric depression.
ECT in treatment-resistant depression.

questionList.questionText: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the office by her husband due to worsening depression.  The husband reports that the patient has become increasingly withdrawn over the past month.  He says, "She abruptly quit her part-time job, stopped answering the phone, and rarely leaves the house now.  Over the past week, she stopped showering and wears the same t-shirt and sweatpants every day."  The patient has difficulty falling asleep and wakes up at 4:30 AM and is up for the rest of the day.  She has a history of 2 depressive episodes previously treated with fluoxetine and venlafaxine but currently takes no psychiatric medications.  Physical examination is remarkable for 4.53 kg (10 lb) weight loss.  Laboratory results are within normal limits.  On mental status examination, the patient whispers and is slow to respond.  She says, "My body is infected with worms."  She has no suicidal ideation but says, "I deserve to die; my body is decaying from the inside anyway."  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's worsening depression and development of delusions are consistent with major depressive disorder (MDD) with psychotic features.  MDD with psychotic features is a severe subtype of depression characterized by delusions and/or hallucinations.  Psychotic features typically have depressive themes such as guilt, worthlessness, and dying (eg, this patient's delusions that her body is decaying and that she deserves to die).

Accurate diagnosis is important because treatment of MDD with psychotic features differs from treatment of nonpsychotic depression (antidepressant monotherapy).  First-line treatment consists of an antidepressant plus an antipsychotic (eg, sertraline and risperidone).  Electroconvulsive therapy is another first-line option, but it is typically reserved for patients who require rapid response due to severe suicidality or refusal to eat or drink.

(Choices A, D, E, and G)  Antipsychotic monotherapy (eg, aripiprazole, quetiapine) or antidepressant monotherapy (eg, mirtazapine, venlafaxine) is not as effective as combination therapy.  Patients with MDD with psychotic features should be treated with a combination of an antidepressant plus an antipsychotic.

(Choice B)  The combination of 2 antidepressants (the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor antidepressant, escitalopram, with the dopamine-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, bupropion) can be considered for the management of nonpsychotic depression that does not respond to monotherapy alone.  However, it would not treat this patient's psychosis.

(Choice C)  The combination of an antidepressant (eg, fluoxetine) and lithium is used in the management of treatment-resistant, nonpsychotic depression and bipolar disorder.  It is not an effective combination for MDD with psychosis.

Educational objective:
Major depressive disorder with psychotic features is a subtype of depression characterized by severe depression and delusions and/or hallucinations.  First-line treatment consists of an antidepressant plus an antipsychotic or electroconvulsive therapy.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes to the urgent care clinic due to fatigue and muscle aches for 2 days.  She says, "I rarely have to use a sick day but today I had to because I feel horrible—my nose won't stop running, and I've got a bad headache.  I think I'm coming down with the flu."  The patient also reports having chills and difficulty sleeping through the night.  She took acetaminophen but has had no symptom relief.  The patient has a 2-year history of depression treated with paroxetine, which she has not taken for the past few days.  She is visiting New York from Chicago for work and forgot to pack her medication.  She takes no other medications.  The patient drinks a glass of wine on most evenings and does not use tobacco.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 134/86 mm Hg, and pulse is 92/min.  On physical examination, the patient appears restless.  There is clear nasal discharge, but nasopharyngeal mucosa appears normal.  Lungs are clear on auscultation, and heart sounds are normal.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  There is a mild tremor in both hands, but no other focal neurological deficits are present.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's sudden onset of flulike symptoms (fatigue, myalgias, chills, headache, rhinorrhea), insomnia, and tremor following abrupt discontinuation of paroxetine is suggestive of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome (ADS).  Other common ADS symptoms include dizziness, nausea, neurosensory disturbances (eg, paresthesia, "electric shock" sensations, vivid dreams), and psychological symptoms (eg, dysphoria, anxiety, irritability).

Symptoms typically begin within 2-4 days of the medication being abruptly stopped or rapidly tapered.  Serotonergic antidepressants with a shorter elimination half-life (eg, paroxetine, venlafaxine), higher doses, and longer duration of treatment are associated with more severe ADS symptoms.  The pathophysiology of ADS is not entirely elucidated:  Longterm use of these antidepressants may affect serotonin levels and transporters (eg, serotonin transporter reduction); upon their abrupt discontinuation, this can lead to hyperserotonergic manifestations, partly due to hypofunction of serotonin transporters (which normally decrease serotonin levels in the synaptic cleft).  Effects on other neurotransmitters (eg, norepinephrine) may explain the other manifestations of ADS (eg, rhinorrhea), and flulike symptoms are classic.

Reinstitution of a serotonergic antidepressant should result in rapid improvement.  Patients prescribed antidepressants with shorter elimination half-lives should be cautioned about the risk of ADS due to accidental or intentional self-discontinuation.

(Choice A)  Urine toxicology would be low-yield in this patient who has no history or signs of recent drug use, and ADS is a better explanation of her constellation of symptoms in the setting of recently being off paroxetine.

(Choices B, C, and F)  Although this patient has prominent physical symptoms (eg, fatigue, myalgias, headache), acute symptom onset following missed doses of antidepressant medication is highly suggestive of ADS rather than an infectious etiology, and restlessness and tremor are not consistent with influenza or Lyme disease.  Further testing for influenza or serologic testing for Lyme disease is not indicated.  Prescribing antibiotics in this patient who is afebrile and shows no signs of bacterial infection would be inappropriate.

(Choice D)  Tremor, restlessness, and elevated heart rate and blood pressure may be seen with mild alcohol withdrawal.  However, alcohol withdrawal would be unlikely in this patient with moderate alcohol consumption and would not explain her chills and rhinorrhea.

Educational objective:
Abrupt discontinuation or rapid taper of short half-life serotonergic antidepressants can result in antidepressant discontinuation syndrome.  Treatment consists of restarting a serotonergic antidepressant.

answerChoiceList.choice: Check urine toxicology for substance abuse
Perform serologic testing for Lyme disease
Prescribe benzodiazepine taper for alcohol withdrawal

questionList.questionText: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after her parents found her attempting to cut her wrists.  The parents say that she is often "moody" but has never done anything like this before.  The patient has been very upset since her boyfriend broke up with her last week.  Examination shows numerous superficial cuts on her forearms in various stages of healing and a fresh deep laceration that requires 5 sutures.  The patient admits to attempting suicide by cutting her wrists.  When asked why she did it, she says, "I don't know.  I felt so alone and angry.  I just didn't want to be here anymore."  The patient avoids eye contact and looks at the ground during the entire interview.  She refuses to answer many questions but admits to feeling depressed over the past few months.  When asked if she would do something like this again, the patient looks down and does not answer.  Her parents want to take the girl to her pediatrician, whom they trust and feel knows the patient very well.  They refuse psychiatric hospitalization, and insist that they will watch their daughter at all times.  The patient wants to go home as well.  Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
questionList.explanationText:
In recent years, suicide has alternated with homicide as the second or third leading cause of death in adolescents; between 5%-10% of adolescents make at least one suicide attempt in a given year.  This patient has recently made a serious suicide attempt and is guarded and evasive when answering questions regarding whether she would attempt it again.  She remains at high risk for another attempt and should be hospitalized (involuntarily, if necessary) for safety.  Although efforts should be made to obtain parental consent, a minor can be involuntarily hospitalized for psychiatric causes without it.  The exact procedures for involuntary psychiatric hospitalization vary from state to state.

Although this patient's healed superficial cuts may represent nonsuicidal self-injury (NSSI), her recent deep laceration was associated with suicidal intent.  In contrast to a suicide attempt (ie, act performed with some intent to die), NSSI may be used to cope with distressing negative affective states; it is seen in a wide range of disorders, including borderline personality, eating, and dissociative disorders.  Some patients engage in both NSSI and suicidal behavior.

(Choices B and C)  Follow-up with the pediatrician and referral to outpatient psychiatric care would be indicated once the patient has been stabilized on the inpatient psychiatric service.  Currently, this patient remains at high risk for suicide, and it would be unsafe to discharge her to outpatient care.

(Choice D)  Waiting 12 hours is unlikely to provide any information that will change the treatment plan for this patient, who is an acute threat to herself.  Holding patients overnight is reasonable in other situations in which they will likely be better able to communicate the next day (eg, no longer intoxicated with alcohol or drugs).

(Choice E)  Safety is the priority at this point, and it would be inappropriate to discharge the patient to her parents, who cannot realistically monitor her at all times.  Documentation of the parents' release of liability does not relieve the physician of the duty to protect the patient.

Educational objective:
Patients who are an acute threat to themselves should be hospitalized (involuntarily, if necessary) for treatment and stabilization.  This principle also applies to minors, even without parental or guardian consent.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Suicide

answerChoiceList.choice: Admit the patient to the hospital involuntarily
Discharge the patient into the care of her pediatrician
Discharge the patient with a next-day psychiatric appointment
Hold the patient in the emergency department overnight for reevaluation in the morning
Release the patient into the parents' custody after they sign a release of liability

questionList.questionText: A 49-year-old woman comes to the office due to depression.  She quit her retail sales job 6 months ago because she could no longer stand all day due to increasing numbness, tingling, and painful, burning sensations in her feet.  The patient has since become increasingly depressed, withdrawn, and preoccupied, with feelings of low self-esteem.  She has a low level of energy, is unable to concentrate to read or watch television, and has lost interest in family and friends.  Medical history is significant for obesity, hypercholesterolemia, and long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Medications include metformin, liraglutide, and rosuvastatin.  The patient has no prior psychiatric history.  After medical evaluation, major depressive disorder is diagnosed.  Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for treating this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus has major depression and diabetic peripheral neuropathy, a distressing and disabling complication that contributes to depression and poor quality of life.

First-line analgesics for neuropathic pain (eg, diabetic peripheral neuropathy) include the following:

  • Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) (eg, duloxetine, venlafaxine)
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) (eg, amitriptyline)
  • Gabapentinoids (eg, gabapentin, pregabalin)

These medications act on nociceptors and neurotransmitters and thereby decrease pain transmission.

The choice of medication depends on comorbid conditions.  Gabapentinoids are best prescribed for patients with neuropathic pain and focal seizure disorder.  SNRIs and TCAs are ideally used in patients with neuropathic pain and comorbid depression.  However, TCAs are less commonly prescribed than SNRIs because of more serious adverse effects (eg, cardiotoxicity, QT prolongation, orthostatic hypotension, urinary retention).  In this patient, duloxetine is an ideal choice because it is a first-line analgesic for neuropathic pain that also treats major depressive disorder.

(Choice A)  Bupropion is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor that has not demonstrated efficacy in relieving neuropathic pain.  It is associated with an increased risk for seizures but with less weight gain and fewer sexual adverse effects than selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).

(Choice B)  Citalopram is an SSRI used to treat major depressive disorder; however, compared to SNRIs, SSRIs have weaker evidence for the treatment of neuropathic pain.

(Choice D)  Mirtazapine is an antidepressant that increases norepinephrine and serotonin release by inhibiting central alpha-2 adrenergic receptors.  It is typically used in patients with insomnia and weight loss due to its sedating and appetite-stimulating properties.  It does not treat neuropathic pain and should be avoided in patients with obesity.

(Choice E)  Trazodone is a serotonin modulator that is highly sedating and commonly used in lower doses for  insomnia.  It does not treat neuropathic pain and can cause orthostatic hypotension, as well as priapism in men.

Educational objective:
Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (eg, duloxetine) have analgesic properties that can be helpful in treating patients with comorbid depression and chronic neuropathic pain, including painful diabetic neuropathy.

questionList.questionText: A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by police at 2:30 AM after she was caught attempting to scale a fence at the White House.  The patient appears highly agitated and paces around the examination room.  She has just flown in from out of state to "meet with the president about a foolproof plan for eliminating worldwide terrorism."  The patient has barely slept for the past week due to her intensive work on this plan.  She speaks rapidly but periodically stops to shout, "I'm going to sue all of you for interfering with my right to meet with the president."  She refuses a cup of water offered by a nurse, flinging it across the room.  The evaluation has to be stopped when the patient begins banging on the door and demanding to leave.  Family history is significant for major depression in her mother.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 148/84 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 22/min.  Urine drug screen is negative.  Administration of which of the following medications is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Acute mania

Clinical features

  • Elevated, irritable, labile mood
  • Increased energy & activity, decreased need for sleep
  • Pressured speech, racing thoughts, distractibility
  • Grandiosity, risky behavior
  • Marked impairment, may have psychotic symptoms

Management

  • Antipsychotics (first- & second-generation)
  • Lithium (avoid in renal disease)
  • Valproate (avoid in liver disease)
  • Combinations in severe mania (eg, antipsychotic plus lithium or valproate)
  • Adjunctive benzodiazepines for insomnia, agitation

This patient's grandiose delusions, decreased need for sleep, pressured speech, and psychomotor agitation causing marked impairment are consistent with a manic episode.  In the absence of any substance or medical cause, the patient would be diagnosed with bipolar I disorder.  First-line treatments for mania include antipsychotics (eg, olanzapine), lithium, and anticonvulsant mood stabilizers (eg, valproate).

Because this patient exhibits acute psychosis (eg, grandiose delusions) and escalating agitation (eg, shouting, banging on the door, throwing a cup of water), an antipsychotic such as olanzapine would be the next step in management because it can be administered intramuscularly and has a rapid onset of action.  Both first- and second-generation antipsychotics are effective in managing mania and associated acute behavioral agitation.

Once this patient is calmer and willing to take oral medication, lithium or an anticonvulsant mood stabilizer could be given.  Combination therapy with an antipsychotic plus lithium or valproate is often necessary to treat severe mania (eg, psychotic features, aggressive behavior, risk of harm to self or others).

(Choices A and G)  Although valproate or carbamazepine can be used in the management of bipolar disorder, they require oral administration (which the patient is currently unlikely to accept) and typically require gradual titration over several days to achieve therapeutic blood levels before they take effect.

(Choice B)  The antipsychotic clozapine requires mandatory monitoring of the complete blood count due to the risk of agranulocytosis; therefore, it is typically reserved for treatment of refractory psychosis.  Olanzapine does not require this level of monitoring and would be a better initial choice for this patient.

(Choices C and E)  Escitalopram (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor) and mirtazapine (alpha-2 receptor antagonist) are both antidepressants.  The use of antidepressants in bipolar disorder is associated with a risk of precipitating or worsening manic episodes.  Antidepressants should generally be discontinued if taken by a patient who has mania.

(Choice D)  The anticonvulsant lamotrigine has the greatest efficacy in treating bipolar depressive (not manic) episodes.  The most significant adverse effect is rash, which can develop into a life-threatening mucocutaneous reaction (ie, Stevens-Johnson syndrome) in approximately 0.1% of patients.

Educational objective:
Management of patients who are agitated and have acute mania consists of antipsychotic medication (administered intramuscularly if needed) to control behavioral disturbances.  Patients experiencing severe mania often require a combination of an antipsychotic and mood stabilizer to manage symptoms effectively.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old man comes to the office due to new-onset depression symptoms.  The patient recently earned his master's degree but has struggled to find employment.  Over the last 3 months, he has developed worsening dysphoria and often struggles to get out of bed in the morning.  He sleeps 14-16 hours each night, feels exhausted throughout the day, has very little appetite, and feels profoundly hopeless and worthless.  The patient used to enjoy playing guitar and socializing with friends but has been unable to enjoy these activities recently.  He has no history of anxiety or depression and does not use alcohol or other recreational substances.  His father has a history of generalized anxiety disorder.  The patient takes no medications and has no known drug allergies.  Physical examination is within normal limits.  A decision is made to start fluoxetine.  Which of the following side effects should the physician discuss with this patient prior to prescribing this medication?
questionList.explanationText:
The informed consent process for prescribing selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) involves counseling patients on short- and long-term side effects.  Common early side effects of SSRIs that typically resolve with time include headache, nausea, insomnia/sedation, anxiety, and dizziness.  Long-term side effects that may be more persistent include sexual dysfunction and weight gain.  Agent-specific drug interactions and side effects (eg, citalopram dose-related QTc prolongation) should also be discussed.  Patients age 18-24 should be informed that studies of their age group have demonstrated an increased risk of suicidality during the initial weeks of SSRI treatment; however, this information should be tempered with information about the risks associated with untreated mental illness.

Other important guidelines to review prior to prescribing SSRIs include time to response and discontinuation considerations.  Patients should be counseled that although some individuals respond after 2 weeks of pharmacotherapy, most take 4-6 weeks to respond.  Patients should be informed that SSRIs must be taken daily and that missed doses or abrupt discontinuation may be associated with SSRI discontinuation syndrome (eg, anxiety, dysphoria, flu-like symptoms).  For this reason, patients should be informed that if they wish to discontinue their SSRI, they will need to undergo a supervised taper process.

(Choice A)  Anxiety, heat intolerance, and tachycardia are potential side effects of levothyroxine.

(Choice B)  Cough, dizziness, and hyperkalemia are known side effects of ACE inhibitor antihypertensives.

(Choice C)  Diarrhea, lactic acidosis, and weakness are potential side effects of metformin.

(Choice D)  Dyslipidemia, hyperglycemia, and sedation are known side effects of second-generation antipsychotics (eg, olanzapine).

(Choice E)  Fatigue, palpitations, and peripheral edema are potential side effects of calcium channel blocker antihypertensives.

(Choice G)  New-onset type 2 diabetes mellitus, hepatic dysfunction, and myalgia are known side effects of HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors (ie, statins).

Educational objective:
Prior to prescribing selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, common early side effects (eg, headache, nausea, insomnia/sedation, anxiety, dizziness) and late side effects (eg, sexual dysfunction, weight gain) should be discussed.  Patients should be advised to avoid abrupt discontinuation and be informed that response typically requires 4-6 weeks of continued use.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors

answerChoiceList.choice: Type 2 diabetes mellitus, hepatic dysfunction, and myalgia

A practical approach to prescribing antidepressants.

questionList.questionText: A 48-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up appointment.  He has a history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and major depression.  Over the past year, the patient has been treated with fluoxetine 20 mg for depression, which was subsequently increased to 40 mg.  He says, "I feel about 50% better.  I'm definitely less sad, and I'm somewhat more interested in my work and spending time with family.  However, I still feel like my energy is low.  I used to go to the gym or attend my son's soccer games on weekends, but now all I want to do is rest in bed or on the couch.  I'm frustrated because I'm eating too much and haven't been able to lose any weight."  Physical examination and routine laboratory tests are unremarkable.  Which of the following medications would be most appropriate to augment this patient's antidepressant therapy?
questionList.explanationText:
The goal of treating major depression is to return patients to their baseline, nondepressed state.  However, many patients do not achieve remission and have persistent depressive symptoms and functional impairment.  For patients who have had a partial response (generally defined as 25%-50% improvement) to first-line treatment and are tolerating their current medication, major augmentation strategies include adding an antidepressant with a different mechanism of action, a second-generation antipsychotic (eg, aripiprazole), lithium, triiodothyronine, or psychotherapy.

This patient with persistent symptoms of low energy and increased appetite had a partial response to first-line treatment with fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).  Bupropion, a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor, has been shown to be an effective augmentation strategy to SSRI therapy.  Bupropion has activating effects and a favorable side-effect profile (no weight gain or sexual side effects), making it a preferred choice for this patient with low energy and weight gain.

Unlike partial responders, nonresponders (ie, patients with little to no improvement or unacceptable tolerability to first-line therapy) generally benefit from switching to a different antidepressant.

(Choice B)  Buspirone is primarily used to treat anxiety disorders.  It may be used as augmentation for major depression when augmentation with a second antidepressant is ineffective.

(Choice C)  Citalopram shares the same mechanism of action as fluoxetine (both are SSRIs).  When prescribing a second antidepressant for augmentation, it is preferable to use a drug with a distinct mechanism of action.

(Choice D)  There is limited evidence to routinely recommend the use of stimulants in adult depression.  There is some evidence for their use in elderly patients who have treatment-resistant depression with prominent symptoms of apathy.

(Choice E)  The antidepressant mirtazapine can be used as augmentation, but its adverse effects of sedation, fatigue, and weight gain would make it a poor choice for this patient.

(Choice F)  Olanzapine, a second-generation antipsychotic, is an effective augmentation strategy for major depression.  However, the risk of weight gain and metabolic adverse effects associated with this drug would make it a less preferred option for a patient with diabetes and hypertension.

(Choice G)  Adding phenelzine, a monoamine oxidase inhibitor, is contraindicated due to the risk of serotonin syndrome when used in combination with an SSRI.

Educational objective:
Augmentation with bupropion is an option for treatment of patients with depression with partial response to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).  Bupropion has activating effects and a favorable side-effect profile (no weight gain or sexual side effects), making it a good choice for patients who are on SSRI therapy but have fatigue, weight gain, or a history of sexual side effects.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office due to sad mood, low motivation, and sleep disturbance over the past several months.  The patient was recently let go from her job because the company was downsizing, and she has been feeling worthless and hopeless about getting another job.  She says, "I'm sure it was just a matter of time before I was fired anyway.  Nothing I try has ever worked out.  I feel like a failure, and I don't think anything will change."  The patient has been reluctant to apply for another job as she assumes she wouldn't be offered the position or would be fired as soon as her shortcomings became evident.  She has had increased appetite and difficulty falling asleep.  The patient has been avoiding her friends, who "try to be supportive but don't seem to understand what I'm going through."  She and the physician decide on a course of nonpharmacological treatment to help with her depression.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Modality

Primary indications

Features

Cognitive-behavioral therapy

  • Depression
  • Generalized anxiety disorder
  • PTSD
  • Panic disorder
  • OCD
  • Eating disorders
  • Negative thought patterns
  • Combines cognitive & behavioral therapy
  • Challenges maladaptive cognitions
  • Targets avoidance with behavioral techniques (relaxation, exposure, behavior modification)

Interpersonal psychotherapy

  • Depression
  • Links symptoms to current relationship conflicts & interpersonal skill deficits

Supportive

psychotherapy

  • Lower functioning; psychotic disorders
  • Patients in crisis
  • Maintains hope; provides encouragement
  • Reinforces coping skills, adaptive defenses

Psychodynamic psychotherapy

  • Higher functioning
  • Personality disorders
  • Builds insight into unconscious conflicts & past relationships
  • Uses transference
  • Breaks down maladaptive defenses

Motivational

interviewing

  • Substance use disorders
  • Nonjudgmental; acknowledges ambivalence & resistance
  • Enhances intrinsic motivation to change

Dialectical behavioral therapy

  • Borderline personality disorder
  • Improves emotion regulation, distress tolerance, mindfulness
  • Decreases self harm; builds skills

Biofeedback

  • Prominent physical symptoms; pain disorders
  • Improves control over physiological reactions to emotional stressors

OCD = obsessive-compulsive disorder; PTSD = post-traumatic stress disorder.

Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is an evidence-based, standardized modality of psychotherapy that targets persistent maladaptive thought patterns and behaviors.  This patient's automatic negative interpretation of experiences and avoidance behavior make her a good candidate for CBT.

CBT is used as monotherapy or in combination with medication to treat a variety of mental illnesses (eg, depression, anxiety disorders, obsessive-compulsive disorder, eating disorders).  Treatment is generally time limited (approximately 5-20 sessions) and structured, and involves homework.  Therapists work with patients to identify and change cognitive distortions, such as overgeneralization (eg, believes nothing ever works out) and catastrophizing (eg, assumes the worst outcome).  Behavioral techniques such as graded exposure target the avoidance behaviors that stem from these distortions.

(Choice A)  Biofeedback involves using signals from the body (ie, heart rate, muscle tension, skin temperature, blood pressure) as indicators of emotional distress.  Patients are taught to identify and control their responses to various stimuli.

(Choice C)  Dialectical behavioral therapy was developed for borderline personality disorder and targets the emotional dysregulation and self-destructive and suicidal behaviors associated with this disorder.

(Choice D)  Interpersonal psychotherapy is an evidence-based therapy primarily used for depression that focuses on the interplay between depressive symptoms and interpersonal stressors.  This patient does not have a specific interpersonal conflict.  Her general cognitive distortions and avoidance behaviors are the main cause of her distress and are best targeted with CBT.

(Choice E)  Motivational interviewing is commonly used to treat substance abuse and involves the therapist assuming a nonjudgmental stance, acknowledging ambivalence, focusing on the patient's motivation for change, and tolerating resistance to change.

(Choice F)  Psychodynamic psychotherapy focuses on the role of unconscious conflict and gaining insight into how past experience shapes present situations.  It does not specifically target thought patterns and avoidance behaviors.

(Choice G)  Supportive psychotherapy is used to reinforce a patient's ability to cope with stressors and is commonly used for low-functioning patients or those in crisis who are at risk of decompensation.  For a more stable patient, such as this woman, CBT provides a more in-depth and targeted approach.

Educational objective:
Cognitive-behavioral therapy focuses on reducing automatic negative thoughts and avoidance behaviors that cause distress.  It is effective as monotherapy or in combination with medication for a wide range of psychiatric disorders.

questionList.questionText: A 64-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of low mood and anxiety that began 2 months ago.  The patient says, "I'm sad and anxious but I can't explain why.  I just have this feeling that something bad is going to happen to me."  He reports having "no energy for anything" and states his coworkers have commented that he seems more reserved than usual.  The patient has had decreased appetite and has lost 9 kg (20 lb) in the last few months.  He has no difficulty falling or remaining asleep and continues to enjoy his hobbies.  The patient formerly smoked tobacco, with a 20-pack-year history, but he does not use alcohol or recreational drugs.  Medical history includes recently diagnosed diabetes mellitus.  His mother died of ovarian cancer at age 52.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  BMI is 19 kg/m2.  The patient is thin and appears anxious.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  He reports no suicidal ideation, hallucinations, or delusions.  TSH level is 4.0 µU/mL.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has some features of major depression (eg, low mood, isolation, weight loss) and anxiety.  However, given his age, smoking history, marked weight loss, and recent diagnosis of diabetes mellitus (despite a lack of obesity), this presentation is concerning for pancreatic cancer.

Depression and associated anxiety may be prodromal features in more than one-third of patients with pancreatic cancer.  Patients may describe nonspecific anxiety, a premonitory sensation ("something bad is going to happen"), and feeling "low" for no reason.  The mechanism is not clear, but hypotheses include an increase in inflammatory cytokines (eg, IL-6), a paraneoplastic syndrome, and alterations in pancreatic function (eg, hormone secretion).

As seen in this patient, new-onset atypical diabetes mellitus (eg, in a thin, older individual) may also precede diagnosis in up to 25% of cases of pancreatic cancer.  In these patients, the pathophysiology of diabetes mellitus is possibly due to cancer-induced beta cell dysfunction or secretion of adrenomedullin (an insulin-regulating peptide hormone).

Therefore, the next step in the work-up of this patient's suspected pancreatic cancer should be CT scan of the abdomen, which is the preferred initial imaging test in nonjaundiced patients presenting with severe weight loss and other suspicious symptoms.

(Choice B)  Electroconvulsive therapy is typically reserved for patients with severe depression who are unresponsive to other therapies or in need of emergency treatment.  Ruling out a malignant etiology for this patient's depression takes priority.

(Choices C and E)  Mirtazapine and paroxetine are antidepressant medications that may be used to treat depression but are not indicated prior to completing an appropriate work-up in a patient with a large number of medical red flags.

(Choice D)  In the absence of localizing neurological symptoms and findings on physical examination, MRI of the brain is not indicated.

Educational objective:
Depression, weight loss, and new-onset diabetes mellitus may be early manifestations of pancreatic cancer.  CT scan of the abdomen is indicated as part of the initial diagnostic evaluation.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Pancreatic cancer

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old man is brought by his wife to the emergency department with a hand injury.  The patient "flew into a rage" and punched a mirror when his wife was late coming home from work.  The wife says, "He is generally not like this, but for the past couple of weeks, he's been extremely irritable.  Everything seems to set him off on a long rant, and I can't get a word in.  I'd be cranky too if I were getting as little sleep as he is—he's been working around the clock."  The patient has a history of behavioral conditions as a child and had a depressive episode in his twenties.  He drinks alcohol socially and does not use drugs.  Physical examination shows multiple lacerations on his right hand but is otherwise normal.  On mental status examination, he is tense and restless.  The patient has no delusions or hallucinations but says, "I can't shut my mind off."  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Manic episode

Clinical
features

  • ≥1 week of elevated or irritable mood & increased energy/activity
  • ≥3 of the following symptoms (4 if mood is irritable only) (DIGFAST mnemonic):
    • Distractibility
    • Impulsivity/indiscretion, risky behavior
    • Grandiosity
    • Flight of ideas/racing thoughts
    • Increased activity/psychomotor agitation
    • Decreased need for sleep
    • Talkativeness/pressured speech

Severity

  • Impaired psychosocial function
  • May have psychotic features (hallucinations, delusions)
  • May require hospitalization

This patient's 2-week history of extreme irritability associated with increased activity, decreased sleep, impulsivity resulting in self-injury, pressured speech (wife "can't get a word in"), and racing thoughts ("can't shut mind off") suggests a manic episode of bipolar I disorder.  His history of a depressive episode in his twenties is consistent with this diagnosis.

Although the classic presentation of mania includes an elevated or euphoric mood, many patients in a manic episode have irritability instead.  This may manifest as uncharacteristic angry outbursts and aggressive behavior, as in this case.  Manic patients typically have markedly increased energy and activity levels.  They often have a decreased need for sleep and may describe feeling energetic despite getting little to no sleep.  Common findings on mental status examination include restlessness; hyperactivity; loud, pressured speech; and grandiosity.

(Choices A and C)  Personality disorders involve lifelong patterns of behavior.  Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by a persistent violation of other people's rights.  In borderline personality disorder, there is a history of unstable relationships, affects, and self-image.  Neither disorder explains this patient's abrupt onset of symptoms.

(Choice D)  Intermittent explosive disorder presents with rage episodes but does not explain this patient's increased activity, decreased sleep, pressured speech, and racing thoughts.  Aggressive outbursts in intermittent explosive disorder are generally short-lived (minutes), whereas manic episodes typically last weeks to months.

(Choice E)  Major depressive disorder is a unipolar disorder that can only be diagnosed in a patient without history of manic episodes.  Based on this patient's current mood episode, his diagnosis is bipolar I disorder.

(Choice F)  Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by mood episodes and psychotic symptoms that also occur in the absence of mood episodes.  This patient has no psychotic symptoms.

Educational objective
Patients with a manic episode of bipolar I disorder may have an irritable rather than euphoric mood, which can manifest as uncharacteristic angry outbursts and aggressive behavior.

questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife due to "uncharacteristic behavior."  The patient started buying large numbers of lottery tickets and decided to quit his job 2 weeks ago.  He has maxed out multiple credit cards buying expensive jewelry for his wife.  The patient has had difficulty sleeping recently and stays up watching TV into the early morning hours.  He says, "I feel really good and finally like what I'm doing."  The patient has no psychiatric history.  Medical history includes recently diagnosed restless leg syndrome, treated with ropinirole.  Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 86/min.  Physical examination is within normal limits.  The patient is restless, appears to be easily distracted, and speaks rapidly.  Complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are within normal limits.  Urine drug screen is negative.  Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
This elderly patient with no psychiatric history now has symptoms suggestive of mania (ie, impulsive overspending, abruptly quitting job, elevated mood, insomnia, pressured speech).  New-onset behavioral changes in an older patient with no psychiatric history should prompt consideration of medical and substance-/medication-related causes.

This patient recently started taking ropinirole, a dopamine agonist medication (used for restless leg syndrome) that has high affinity for D2 and D3 receptors.  Treatment with dopamine agonists, even at therapeutic doses, increases the risk of impulse control disorders that may present with manic-like signs and symptoms.  In the absence of a history of impulse control problems, manic or depressive episodes, or medical conditions known to cause mania, this patient is most likely experiencing a dopamine agonist–induced impulse control disorder.  Other impulsive behaviors that may occur with dopamine agonist therapy include pathological gambling, compulsive shopping and eating, and hypersexuality.

The best initial step is to discontinue the offending medication (ie, ropinirole) and monitor the patient's mental status.  Medication-induced behavioral changes are usually reversible and resolve quickly once the medication is stopped.

(Choice A)  Vitamin B12 deficiency has been associated with neuropsychiatric symptoms including depression, psychosis, cognitive impairment, and dementia.  It is an unlikely cause of manic symptoms in this patient who has a normal complete blood count and no neurologic findings.

(Choice B)  An MRI of the head may potentially be part of the workup of behavioral changes, but it would not be considered the first step in this patient with no focal neurologic findings.  The first step would be to discontinue ropinirole.

(Choices C and D)  Both lithium and lorazepam may be used in the treatment of an acute manic episode in the context of bipolar disorder; however, most cases of bipolar disorder present at a younger age, and the temporal relationship with the recent diagnosis of restless leg syndrome is more suggestive of ropinirole-induced manic-like adverse effects.

Educational objective:
Ropinirole and other dopamine agonists can induce impulse control disorders that may present with a manic-like syndrome.  The treatment of choice in these situations is discontinuation of the offending agent.

questionList.questionText:
A 28-year-old fourth-year medical student is brought to the emergency department by 3 hospital security officers after causing a disturbance in the medical director's office.  On questioning, the student says that he has developed a "simple cure for cancer."  He is extremely excited about this discovery but is perplexed that the medical director does not take him seriously.  He says that this discovery will be praised in the medical and scientific communities and will result in a Nobel Prize.  The patient has had "endless energy" and "a million ideas" in his head for the past week.  He has difficulty focusing on answering questions at times and becomes irritable and hostile when efforts are made to redirect him.  Medical history is significant for depression at age 19.  Family history is significant for adult polycystic kidney disease in his father.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg, pulse is 94/min, and respirations are 16/min.  Review of systems and physical examination are otherwise unremarkable.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin13.1 g/dL
Hematocrit39%
Mean corpuscular volume92 μm3
Platelets220,000/mm3
Leukocytes9,200/mm3
Serum chemistry
Sodium138 mEq/L
Potassium4.1 mEq/L
Chloride106 mEq/L
Bicarbonate24 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen28 mg/dL
Creatinine1.9 mg/dL
Calcium9.2 mg/dL
Glucose112 mg/dL
Liver function tests
Total bilirubin1.0 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin0.3 mg/dL
Alanine aminotransferase22 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase19 U/L

Urine drug screen is negative.  Which of the following medications is most appropriate for long-term management of this patient's illness?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's grandiose delusions, racing thoughts, distractibility, increased energy, and irritability are highly suggestive of a manic episode.  His history of depression at age 19 and now manic symptoms, with apparent good functioning between episodes, support a diagnosis of bipolar I disorder.  Bipolar disorder is a highly recurrent illness.  Following stabilization of acute symptoms, this patient will require maintenance treatment to delay or prevent recurrence of new mood episodes.  Commonly used first-line mood stabilizers for bipolar maintenance include lithium and valproate.  The second-generation antipsychotic quetiapine and the anticonvulsant lamotrigine have also demonstrated efficacy.

This patient's elevated creatinine level, diastolic hypertension, and family history of polycystic kidney disease in his father suggests possible renal dysfunction, making valproate the preferred treatment over lithium (Choice C).  Lithium is excreted unchanged by the kidneys and may build up to toxic levels when used in patients with renal dysfunction.  Long-term use of lithium has been associated with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus and chronic tubulointerstitial nephropathy, which in rare cases can progress to end-stage renal disease.  Valproate, in contrast, is not nephrotoxic, although periodic monitoring of liver function tests and platelets is necessary due to the medication's rare association with hepatotoxicity and thrombocytopenia.

(Choice A)  Bupropion is a norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor.  Like all antidepressants, it may induce mania and therefore is not an appropriate choice for maintenance treatment.

(Choice B)  The first-generation antipsychotic haloperidol can be used for acute stabilization of manic episodes, but it is not preferred for maintenance treatment due to the associated risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.

(Choice D)  Topiramate is an anticonvulsant that has not demonstrated efficacy in acute or maintenance treatment of bipolar disorder.

Educational objective:
Lithium and valproate are first-line options for bipolar disorder maintenance treatment.  Lithium is excreted unchanged by the kidneys and should generally be avoided in patients with renal dysfunction due to the risk of systemic toxicity and long-term nephrotoxic effects.
